channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Shooting at Sri Lanka Campaign Rally Leaves 1 Dead and 12 Hurt
item.description: The finance minister, Ravi Karunanayake, who was campaigning for a parliamentary election, called the violence “an act of political terrorism.”
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A police officer at the scene of a shooting at a political campaign meeting in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Friday.

item.title: Greek Debt Crisis Adds to a Spike in Burglaries and Robberies
item.description: Fleeing the banks for fear of losing their euro deposits, many Greeks have stashed cash and valuables under the proverbial mattress, making them vulnerable to thieves.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers patrolled in Athens on Tuesday. Reports of burglaries and robberies in Greece were on the rise for the first six months of the year, suggesting that hidden valuables in homes have become enticing targets for thieves.

item.title: Amnesty International Weighs Decriminalization of Prostitution
item.description: A proposal by the human rights group to advocate the elimination of penalties in the sex trade, to be taken up at a conference in Dublin, has drawn denunciation from women’s groups.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sex workers in windowed booths waited for customers in Seoul, South Korea. As the human rights group Amnesty International considers pressing for decriminalization of prostitution, some countries are pushing toward harsher penalties for those who pay for sex.

item.title: Jewish Arsonists Suspected in West Bank Attack That Killed Palestinian Toddler
item.description: The attack was branded as terrorism by Israeli and Palestinian politicians, and shocked consciences on both sides of the simmering conflict.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Hebrew graffiti reading “revenge” was spray-painted on a house that was set alight in an attack in the West Bank village of Duma.

item.title: Beijing Defeats Almaty in Bid to Host 2022 Winter Olympics
item.description: The Chinese capital beat the Kazakh city in an International Olympic Committee vote, becoming the first city to host both the Summer and Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Members from the Beijing delegation celebrated after their city was awarded the hosting rights to the 2022 Winter Olympics at the International Olympic Committee meeting in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Friday.

item.title: Zimbabwean Official Urges Extradition of Dentist Who Killed Cecil the Lion
item.description: Oppah Muchinguri, the country’s environment minister, said Dr. Walter J. Palmer, a 55-year-old dentist and big-game hunter from Minnesota, had broken Zimbabwe’s laws.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The killing of Cecil, who was the subject of research at the University of Oxford, has spurred global outrage on social media and beyond, and forced Dr. Walter J. Palmer into hiding.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Police Raids on Chinese Lawyers: The View From the Inside
item.description: Photographs and video from a lawyer and a legal assistant attest to the recent raids, which often occurred at night and without detention or search warrants.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The view through the door of the Guangzhou apartment of He Yanyun, a legal assistant, as police officers demanded to enter on July 22.

item.title: Réunion Debris Probably From Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, Australian Officials Say
item.description: They cautioned that final confirmation about the part found on the remote French island of Réunion would not come from Australia.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Workers searched the beach for possible debris near where part of an airplane was found washed up on the island of Reunion on Friday.

item.title: Experimental Ebola Vaccine in Guinea Shows Promise, Report Says
item.description: The report, published in the British medical journal The Lancet, indicated that the vaccine “might be safe and highly efficacious in preventing Ebola virus disease.”
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK

item.title: Britain Limits Visit by the Chinese Artist Ai Weiwei
item.description: The British government granted Mr. Ai a visa, but not a standard six-month business visa, saying he had neglected to declare that he had been convicted of a crime.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Ai Weiwei in Munich on Thursday with Wang Fen and their son, Ai Lao.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Saudi Arabia's New Sunni Alliance
item.description: Last year, the kingdom declared the Muslim Brotherhood “terrorists.” This year, it embraces them as friends.
item.dc:creator: HUSSEIN IBISH
item.media:description: Yemenis marching in the southwestern city of Taiz in favor of the Saudi-led coalition that is battling Shiite Houthi rebels.

item.title: Ai Weiwei Says He May Cancel Trip to Britain Over Visa Dispute
item.description: Mr. Ai was denied a regular six-month business visa, and he instead received one that allows him to stay in the country from Sept. 9 to 29, the time of his planned travel.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei arrived in Munich on Thursday. He left China this week for the first time in four years after the Chinese authorities returned his passport.

item.title: Taliban Announce New Leader, and Pick 2 Deputies From Hard-Line Wing
item.description: The move greatly elevated the standing of the extremist Haqqani wing, and it may in turn complicate efforts to resume peace talks with Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Protesters Upset Over Textbook Changes March on Taiwan’s Education Ministry
item.description: Hundreds of students converged on Taiwan’s Ministry of Education and briefly entered the grounds of the legislature in protests over history textbook changes that they say place undue emphasis on links to mainland China.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Big Turnout for Madame Chiang Kai-shek Estate
item.description: Dozens of people with ties to China have expressed interest in buying the Long Island property of the late Madame Chiang Kai-shek, according to the company handling the sale.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:description: An undated photo of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: China’s vs. Its Human Rights Lawyers
item.description: The current crackdown shows how the Communist Party fears its legitimacy to rule could crumble.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: XIAO GUOZHEN

item.title: For Sympathetic Ear, More Chinese Turn to Smartphone Program
item.description: A new Microsoft chatbot called Xiaoice has become something of a hit in China with responses based on actual conversations culled from the Internet.
item.dc:creator: JOHN MARKOFF and PAUL MOZUR
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zhang Ran, 26, chatted with Xiaoice in Beijing. Millions of young Chinese use the smartphone program.

item.title: 3 Former Executives to Be Prosecuted in Fukushima Nuclear Disaster
item.description: The decision to proceed with criminal cases, the first to arise from the 2011 meltdowns, marked a victory for citizens’ groups.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: North Korea Says Detained Canadian Pastor Confessed to Crimes
item.description: The Rev. Lim Hyeon-soo said at a news conference in Pyongyang that he had conducted “anti-D.P.R.K. missionary activities,” according to a state-run news agency.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: The Rev. Lim Hyeon-soo in a picture released on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Films Find Their Audience — and It’s Huge
item.description: China’s “domestic film protection period,” the summer weeks when foreign films are largely blocked from Chinese theaters, is helping at least one movie set box-office records.
item.dc:creator: CECILIA LI
item.media:description: Huba, the little monster of "Monster Hunt"
